channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: U.S. Drawing Southeast Asia Closer With California Summit
item.description: Competition with China will be the subtext as President Obama hosts Asean leaders beginning on Monday in Rancho Mirage, Calif.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: President Obama on his way out of the White House. Since his administration’s ‘‘pivot to Asia,’’ America has been in direct competition with China for economic power in Southeast Asia.

item.title: Independent, Once a British News Power, Ending Print Edition
item.description: The paper, which shook up Britain’s journalism establishment in the 1980s before falling on hard times, will publish only online, its owner says.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: The demise of the print editions of The Independent — and its weekly counterpart, The Independent on Sunday — is a blow to Britain’s vibrant and fiercely competitive news media scene.

item.title: Emoji Makers Find Muse in a Kim: Jong-un, Not Kardashian West
item.description: A new website allows users to send images of the North Korean leader smiling, crying and walking, as well as rockets and a nuclear mushroom cloud.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH OLIVENNES

item.title: Zika Virus Test Is ‘Weeks, Not Years’ Away, W.H.O. Says
item.description: Large-scale clinical trials for a potential vaccine are not expected for at least 18 months, however, the World Health Organization said.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.media:description: A mother held her 4-month-old son, who was born with microcephaly, in Olinda, Brazil, on Thursday.

item.title: Loubna Abidar, Moroccan Actress, Finds Fame Tinged With Fury
item.description: Ms. Abidar, 30, who plays a strong-minded prostitute in the acclaimed film “Much Loved,” was forced to move to France after a backlash in her homeland.
item.dc:creator: AIDA ALAMI
item.media:credit: Pierre Terdjman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Loubna Abidar in Paris this week. Ms. Abidar’s troubles began in May when “Much Loved,” directed by Nabil Ayouch, had its premiere at the Cannes Film Festival.

item.title: United Arab Emirates to Bolster Its Efforts Against ISIS, U.S. Says
item.description: American officials have pressed Arab states to step up their contributions to the fight against the militant group.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.media:description: The American defense secretary, Ashton B. Carter, right, during a coalition meeting at NATO’s headquarters in Brussels on Thursday.

item.title: Sunni Resentment Muddles Prospect of Reunifying Iraq After ISIS
item.description: Without plans for reconciliation and rebuilding places like Anbar, critics say, the American approach risks leaving fertile ground for the Islamic State.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: Iraqis who fled regions controlled by the Islamic State near Falluja arrived on the eastern outskirts of Ramadi on Tuesday after pro-government troops retook the area.

item.title: Pakistan Says It Foiled Plot to Free Militant Behind Daniel Pearl’s Death
item.description: A Pakistani general said militants with ties to Al Qaeda and Lashkar-e-Jhangvi planned to free about 100 prisoners, among them the British-born Ahmed Omar Sheikh.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: Ahmed Omar Sheikh at the high court in Karachi, Pakistan, in 2002.

item.title: Pakistan Says It Foiled Plot to Free Militant Behind Daniel Pearl’s Death
item.description: A Pakistani general said militants with ties to Al Qaeda and Lashkar-e-Jhangvi planned to free about 100 prisoners, among them the British-born Ahmed Omar Sheikh.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: Ahmed Omar Sheikh at the high court in Karachi, Pakistan, in 2002.

item.title: Sinosphere: Q. and A.: Zha Jianying on Remembering the Cultural Revolution
item.description: Ms. Zha, who wrote an introduction to the harrowing Chinese memoir “The Cowshed,” said it rekindled the nightmarish memories from her own childhood.
item.category: The Cowshed: Memories of the Chinese Cultural Revolution (Book)
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: With placards hanging around their necks, two men denounced as counterrevolutionary elements were driven through the streets of Beijing on Jan. 8, 1967, during the early months of the Cultural Revolution.

item.title: Britain Accuses China of Violating Treaty in Hong Kong Bookseller’s Case
item.description: The British foreign secretary said the apparent abduction of Lee Bo was a “serious breach” of treaty commitments between Beijing and London.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: A rally in Hong Kong last month after the disappearance of five people connected to a publishing house.

item.title: Francis’s Visit to Mexico Comes as Country Struggles With Many Ills
item.description: The government is hoping for a credibility boost from the pope’s visit, but his itinerary also poses a risk by highlighting some of the state’s most obvious failings.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED, JIM YARDLEY and PAULINA VILLEGAS
item.media:description: A billboard welcoming Pope Francis on Wednesday in Ciudad Juárez, Mexico.

item.title: Taiwanese City Moves Against Builder’s Holdings After Earthquake
item.description: Tainan has told local government agencies to monitor the 30 real estate holdings to prevent their sale in the event the victims’ families want to sue.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Defense Secretary Says Anti-ISIS Coalition Has Agreed to ‘Step Up’
item.description: Secretary Ashton B. Carter said he had received pledges from 90 percent of the 40 countries fighting the Islamic State, but he did not offer specifics.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.media:description: An Air Force C-17 Globemaster returned to base at an undisclosed location in the Persian Gulf in January after delivering cargo to Baghdad. The United States and other coalition countries use bases in the region to transport troops and equipment for the fight against ISIS.

item.title: Ex-Guantánamo Detainee Is Freed From Moroccan Prison
item.description: Younis Shokuri had remained in custody for months despite assurances from Morocco that he would probably be released soon after his transfer from the prison in Cuba.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE and AIDA ALAMI
item.media:description: A former Guantánamo detainee, Younis Shokuri, was released from a Moroccan jail on Thursday.

item.title: U.S. Issues Sanctions Against Three ISIS Leaders
item.description: The leaders were said to be crucial to sustaining the militant group’s flow of cash, and the sanctions will freeze any assets or property belonging to the men.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: Kurdish forces watched a burning oil well last year near Hole, Syria, a town held by the Islamic State. Oil has been a major source of revenue for the jihadist group.

item.title: U.S. and Russia Announce Plan for Humanitarian Aid and a Cease-Fire in Syria
item.description: Relief would be sent to besieged cities within days, and a “cessation of hostilities” would go into effect in a week, American and Russian officials announced.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: Syrians waiting at a crossing gate near Kilis, Turkey, to return to Syria on Thursday.

item.title: Swedish Bank Move Creates a Global Shudder
item.description: Investors worry that a decision by the Swedish central bank to lower its short-term rate to minus 0.50 is going to worsen the global economy.
item.dc:creator: LANDON THOMAS Jr.
item.media:description: The New York Stock Exchange on Thursday, when the Dow fell 1.6 percent and the Standard & Poor’s index fell 1.2 percent.

item.title: With Shares Plunging, Deutsche Bank Sets Out to Prove It Can Be Fixed
item.description: Regarded in Germany as a national asset and a symbol of economic might, Deutsche Bank now sits at the center of the “too big to fail” debate.
item.dc:creator: PETER EAVIS and JACK EWING
item.media:description: John Cryan, right, and Juergen Fitschen, co-chief executives of Deutsche Bank, at a news conference in January.

item.title: At Least 49 Inmates Killed in Mexican Prison Riot
item.description: A fight between two gangs turned into a deadly riot in an overcrowded, dated penitentiary in the northern city of Monterrey.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN
item.media:description: People waited for news outside Topo Chico Prison in Monterrey, Mexico, on Thursday.
